newsitem.title: USA: Spyglass falls on earnings warning.
newsitem.headline: Spyglass falls on earnings warning.

text.p: Spyglass Inc. stock fell 10 percent Thursday after the Internet software company said it would report a fiscal first-quarter loss at least 10 times worse than analysts had expected.
Analysts blamed a software licensing agreement with giant Microsoft Corp.
Spyglass slipped $1.25 to $11.25 on the Nasdaq market after saying it would report a loss of between 10 cents and 13 cents a share on revenues of $4 million.

Wall Street had been expecting a loss of just 1 cent per share on far greater revenues, according to First Call, which tracks analysts' estimates. In last year's fiscal first quarter, the Naperville, Ill.-based company reported a profit of $722,000, or 6 cents a share.

Spyglass said it did not expect revenues from Microsoft of more than $400,000 for the quarter, the minimum payment for the Internet software deal. The company's filtering software blocks access to objectionable material on the Internet.

"I was a little bit surprised -- not that they had a shortfall, because they are clearly going through a transition, but that the shortfall came from Microsoft," said Mark D'Annolfo, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill.
Spyglass recently entered the deal with Microsoft under which the software giant would use Spyglass SurfWatch software on its Microsoft Internet Explorer Web browser and therefore pay royalties.
Analysts said they had expected total fiscal first-quarter revenues of about $6 million to $6.7 million, and, of that, at least $1 million to $2 million was to come from Microsoft.

"It's a $2 million shortfall ... by my model, $1 (million) to $1.5 million (of the shortfall in the quarter) is due to Microsoft," said Abhishek Gami, an analyst with brokerage Nesbitt Burns Securities Inc. "Spyglass has not cut back on their spending, so it all hits their bottom line."
Spyglass also said in a news release it planned to exercise its contractual right to audit Microsoft's records.

"There is a disagreement on what is owed to us, and that's why we're doing the audit," said Spyglass spokesman Randy Pitzer. He declined to comment further because the company is still in talks with Microsoft.
A Microsoft spokesman said it was ahead of schedule on royalty payments to Spyglass, but hoped to resolve the dispute amicably.
"We believe the review will show that we are actually ahead of our payments to Spyglass because we have prepaid several million dollars of royalties," Microsoft spokesman Mark Murray said.
Murray declined to comment on the specific provisons of the royalty agreement, saying details were confidential.

According to a source familiar with the agreement between the companies, the royalties apply only to versions of Microsoft's Internet Explorer for Windows 3.X and MacIntosh systems. Those systems account for a smaller part of Microsoft's Internet browser market. The royalty agreement does not apply to the successful Windows 95 browser versions, the source said.
Spyglass said the arrangement was a combination of fixed fees and royalties, but declined to provide the breakdown for various computer system products.
Nesbitt Burns' Gami said that, based on his reading of the contract between Spyglass and Microsoft, royalties apply to Windows 95 as well as other systems.
"It is possible that's where the misunderstanding is," Gami said.
Microsoft's total share of the Internet browser market has been estimated as high as 25 percent.
